You win a small pot of, let's say, £200, and you keep on playing with your mind thinking "this is most likely going to happen again" but it never, ever does

Music from "back in the day" is objectively better than music today which was proven in a study I read but cannot find again. The report stated that there was a distinguishable downward trend that showed how music became measurably less and less good over time. This trend was actually caused by shifting practices of record companies. You see, previously, a record company scout would actively search for bands/performers who had a noticeable level of success and decide whether or not to take a risk on that group/performer. The risk was high and so was the reward when things turned out well. Just take a look at the Beatles or the Rolling Stones for example. But the failure was catastrophic when things did not turn out. Record companies recognized this pattern and started seeking out ways to minimize the risk of huge loss even at the cost of huge reward because more money can be made overall by several low-risk chances than by a few high-risk chances. So, record companies gradually began taking fewer and fewer risks and began turning away from seeking talented individuals/groups and started more and more to look for what has mass appeal. The turning point came in the 90's and the major record companies stopped the old practices altogether. Now, they use mathematical formulae to determine what has mass appeal and lasting residual effect. Songs use far fewer words and notes to drive up repetitiveness to increase the chance that a catchy tune will stick in your head better and longer. According to another report from just a few years ago, over 80% of all new pop music produced in the US was only being written by just 2 men whose job it was to write catchy tunes with mass appeal.
TLDR: Bands like Nirvana will never get the chance that they would've gotten decades ago because greed has spoiled the industry.

i remember in grade 5 at age 10, was the year my sister would graduate from elemtary school and she is 3 years older than me. when i realized that it hit me SO hard. the fact that it seemed like a second ago we were back in our first appartment celebrating her 6 bday and now shes about to start high school. when i realized everyone i luv and i continue getting closer to death and furthur from the happiest memories, every night was a miserable fight in my head until i would fall asleep. i would even cry sometimes becuz i was i wanted to stay in these happy moments where everyone i luv is still alive and we r all having fun times. for example, everytime i would watch a nice childhood family movie with my mom and my sister and sometimes my dad id be in the best mood when it starts. but after it starts a couple seconds later i no longer just watching a movie, but thinking, this movie will end in this amount of time. which is what i realize now, is the reason i was so sad about time and getting closer to death. i wasnt living in the moment, i was looking forward to the worst parts of my future. from when an awesome movie would end to an awesome field trip to end to one of my loved ones growing and growing till their end. thats what i was focused on, instead whats happening in that moment. 5 years past, im 15 and i think ive become more chill about it. before when ppl would bluntly say ur not getting any younger on a tv show for example, id feel so sick in the stomach and id feel sad right away. now im the one saying it and embracing the positive meaning out of those kind of sayings. now i realize, everything that happens happens. thats the moment u r living in, and u r still young. so enjoy and embrace it. focus on that and not the fact that it will end at a certain moment. the best part about dying, is that when u do die, u wont even know ur dead

The biases are not mistakes but heuristics that allow more accurate decisions with less thinking the vast majority of the time. Eg availability makes sense because if you let's say move to a new place and now new things happen to you, you're more likely to experience those things than things from your past. Similarly weather, political systems could change.

Before the invenion of the TV the availibility heursitic was also very useful. If you know a few examples of a certain illness causing problems then you're in more danger. (you woldn't know what happens at the other end of the world)

In short, those heuristics are not mistakes but effective statistical tools. It is very recent that even more accurate statistical tools became available to mankind.

Shouldn't it be: He told them to put as little armour they could on the parts of the planes that WERE being hit?

Wikipedia:"During World War II, Wald applied his statistical skills when considering how to minimize bomber losses to enemy fire. Researchers from the Center for Naval Analyses had conducted a study of the damage done to aircraft that had returned from missions, and had recommended that armor be added to the areas that showed the most damage. Wald noted that the study only considered the aircraft that had survived their missions—the bombers that had been shot down were not present for the damage assessment. The holes in the returning aircraft, then, represented areas where a bomber could take damage and still return home safely. Wald proposed that the Navy instead reinforce the areas where the returning aircraft were unscathed, since those were the areas that, if hit, would cause the plane to be lost.[4][5] This is still considered today seminal work in the then-fledgling discipline of operational research."

Your life expectancy results are total bullshit. That's DEATH expectation. That's the mean of the probability distribution of people's age who die TODAY. But don't you get it? That has more to do with what the life expectation was 70 years ago than the life expectation of someone alive today who has yet to die. NOBODY knows what LIFE expectation is today, the mean of the probability distribution of the time of death of someone alive NOW, because no one knows what technologies will be available tomorrow to extend that someone's life. In other words, just because the average age of the people who DIE today is 70, that doesn't mean someone who is currently 35 should expect to have 35 years left on average, via new technology, that someone could be alive in 50, 100, or 1000 years, and no one has any idea what the probabilities are of that. The day the human race has no further developments and technology 50 years from now will be expected to be the same as it is today, THAT is the day that death expectation will equal life expectation. Why is anyone still going on about death expectation as if it's the same as life expectation? AND it gets worse than that. Because the 35 year old, even if life expectation WAS the same as death expectation, would expect to live longer than 35 years longer, because the average of 70 would include in its average, all those people who died before the age of 35, but the 35-year-old is already past that point, you would need to average the death age of everyone who is in the set of people who live to the age of 35 or more (in other words exclude from the group of people you're averaging, everyone younger than 35 when they died, and if they were included, they would lower the average death age, so leaving them out increases the average), so the 35 year old would expect to live 40 or 45 years more then on average, because it's a distribution on a conditional probability, maybe for every additional second he lives at the age of 35, that adds an additional 1/10 second on to the expected time of his death, while for a 80 year old, every additional second adds maybe half a second on to the expected time of death.

Measuring risk in terms of micromorts has a very significant drawback, it doesn't actually measure loss of value and thus amount we would be willing to pay to reduce them. To understand why, lets consider the following.

Lets say that there is are two buttons in front of you, pressing one kills you now, and pressing the other kills you in ten years. You have to press one or else you will die immediately and your whole family will also. Which one do you press?

Obviously the one that kills you in ten years. But now lets look at it in terms of micromorts, Both have a 100% thance to kill you so both are 1,000,000 micromorts, and if micromorts were what you really cared about both buttons would be the same.

So what's the missing piece? Time. I don't mind dieing, I would do it a lot except that it has this problem where I have to stop living. I do care about living. I want lots of time alive.

So even if the 5 cigarettes would be just as likely to kill me as skydiving, the difference is when it will kill me. Skydiving will kill me soon, smoking will kill me much later.

Sometimes, to account for this, in medical calculations they use quality years of life that can be gained by a procedure. That makes more sense. I do care about the number of years of quality life I have. I don't care about weather I die from cancer, hitting the ground, or gun violence so long as I get the same amount of quality life before each.

Rollercoasters are meant to be terrifying, but in a controlled way; you are on a closed track strapped into a car which follows the exact same path hundreds of times a day, day after day, year after year without incident. Furthermore, the frequency of which people ride airplanes and rollercoasters is far less than how often people ride in a vehicle.

That's why people are so afraid of sharks - they can't control them. And though the possibility of being killed by a vending machine is greater than being killed by shark, sharks are still most feared animals.

I dislike the cigarette analogy. Cigarettes are much, much, more harmful than the chance of being blown up by a stick of dynamite. For one, arguably a factor of what makes death undesirable is the pain that it causes - being blown up lasts maybe 3 seconds, is physically not that painful. Watching a loved one become slowly crippled by their nicotine addiction, reaching the point where you know there is nothing you can do and you are condemned to die, and then fighting off the diseases in a painful and often undignified fashion is a terrible thing.

For another, while it is statistically true that around one person a day dies from cigarette related illnesses, many people who don't necessarily die from cigarettes, they certainly are impacted in negative ways as well. Your lifespan is shortened. You will face health problems, which even if non-fatal still impact your quality of life. Your psychology is impacted, and not in a good way. You lose out on time, your relationships and career paths may suffer. I would much rather live a happy and meaningful existence, free from toxins in my bloodstream, and die suddenly one day than die a slow death grappling with an addiction.

Obviously this is still a really well done video and interesting as always Vsauce, but I thought I should point that out!

Hey Michael, I have a question about memories. Let's say there's 2 people: Jack and John. They know each other for 25 years and then John loses his memory. He doesn't remember anything when he wakes up. Not a thing from twenty five years of life. His friend, Jack, has had to live through that experience and knows everything that happened since his memory starting point: childhood. John's memory starting point, however, would be from the point he regained consciousness. So mentally, he hasn't lived his past. Only his present. So for any person, would it be safe to say that if they can remember their past and current present that they won't lose their memories? Since for the individual it would be an instantaneous thing and time would be an illusion for them? They wouldn't wake up NOW for US, they'd wake up NOW for THEM which would be in their acquaintances' future

You may have recently come across a realistic-looking news story on the web: headlined "British Scientists Clone Dinosaur," it discusses "a baby Apatosaurus nicknamed Spot" that was supposedly incubated at the John Moore University College of Veterinary Medicine, in Liverpool. What makes the story so unnerving is the realistic-looking "photograph" of a baby sauropod that accompanies it, which looks a bit like the creepy baby in David Lynch's classic film Eraserhead. Needless to say, this "news item" is a complete hoax, albeit a very entertaining one.

Jurassic Park made it all look so easy: in a remote laboratory, a team of scientists extracts DNA from the guts of hundred-million-year-old mosquitoes petrified in amber (these pesky bugs, of course, feasted on dinosaur blood before they died). The dinosaur DNA is combined with frog DNA (an odd choice, considering that frogs are amphibians rather than reptiles), and then, by some mysterious process that's presumably too difficult for the average moviegoer to follow, the result is a living, breathing Velociraptor straight out of the Cretaceous period.

In real life, though, cloning a dinosaur would be a much, much more difficult undertaking. That hasn't prevented an eccentric Australian billionaire, Clive Palmer, from recently announcing his plans to clone dinosaurs for a real-life, down-under Jurassic Park. (One presumes that Palmer made his announcement in the same spirit that Donald Trump tested the waters for a presidential bid--as a way of attracting attention and headlines.) Is Palmer one shrimp short of a full barbie, or has he somehow mastered the scientific challenge of dinosaur cloning? Let's take a closer look at what's involved.

Dinosaur Cloning Step #1: Obtain a Dinosaur Genome

DNA--the molecule that encodes all of an organism's genetic information--has a notoriously complex, and easily breakable, structure consisting of millions of "base pairs" strung in a specific sequence. The fact is that it's extremely difficult to extract a full strand of DNA from a 10,000-year-old Woolly Mammoth frozen in permafrost; imagine what the odds are for a dinosaur, even an extremely well-fossilized one, that has been encased in sediment for over 65 million years. Jurassic Park had the right idea, DNA-extraction-wise; the trouble is that dinosaur DNA would degrade even in the relatively isolated confines of a mosquito's fossilized tummy.
The best we can reasonably hope for--and even that's a stretch--is to recover scattered fragments of a particular dinosaur's DNA, accounting for perhaps one or two percent of its entire genome. Then, the hand-waving argument goes, we might be able to supplement these DNA fragments with strands obtained from the modern descendants of dinosaurs, the birds. But which species of bird? How much of its DNA? And, without knowing what a complete Diplodocus genome looks like, how would we know where to insert the dinosaur DNA remnants?

Dinosaur Cloning Step 2: Find a Suitable Host

Ready for more disappointment? An intact dinosaur genome, even if one were ever miraculously to be found, wouldn't be sufficient, by itself, to clone a dinosaur. You can't just inject the DNA into, say, an unfertilized chicken egg, then sit back and wait for your Apatosaurus to hatch. The fact is that most vertebrates need to gestate in extremely specific conditions, and, at least for a short period of time, in a living body (even a fertilized chicken egg spends a day or two in the mother hen's oviduct before it's laid).

So what would be the ideal "foster mom" for a cloned dinosaur? Clearly, if we're talking about a genus on the larger end of the spectrum, we'll need a correspondingly hefty bird, if only because dinosaur eggs were much bigger than chicken eggs. (That's another reason you couldn't hatch a baby Apatosaurus out of a chicken egg; it's just not capacious enough.) An ostrich might fit the bill, but we're so far out on a speculative limb now that we might as well just consider cloning a giant, extinct bird like Gastornis or Argentavis!

Dinosaur Cloning Step 3: Cross Your Fingers (or Claws)

Let's put the odds of successfully cloning a dinosaur into perspective. Consider the common practice of artificial gestation involving human beings--i.e., in vitro fertilization. No cloning or manipulation of genetic material is involved, just introducing a sperm to an egg, cultivating the resulting zygote in a test-tube for a couple of days, and implanting the embryo-in-waiting into the mother's uterus. Even this technique fails more often than it succeeds; most times, the zygote simply doesn't "take," and any genetic abnormalities will cause a termination of the pregnancy weeks, or months, after the implantation.

Compared to IVF, cloning a dinosaur is almost infinitely more complicated. We simply don't have access to the proper environment in which a dinosaur embryo can gestate, or the means to tease out the information encoded in dinosaur DNA in the proper sequence and with the proper timing. Even if we got as far as implanting a full dinosaur genome into an ostrich egg, the embryo would, in the vast majority of cases, simply fail to develop. Long story short: pending some major advancements in science, there's no need to book a trip to Australia's Jurassic Park!


Author: Bob Strauss

If I smoke only 5 cigarettes in my life, it simply will not equal the risk of a skydiving jump because WE DON'T KNOW exactly wha the effect on lifetime health of 5 cigarettes is. We might know what 5 cigarette a day for the average person does and then divide that by the shortened lifespan but that simply isn't accurate.

I could be 10 times worse or 10 times better than we think but these statistics are obscuring the fact that we don't actually know to any meaningful degree what the impact of 5 cigarettes actually is !

It's not real. It seems to me that we've gotten to a point where we would be willing to trade in a little bit of our freedom for the feeling of safety. 
Simply so we can live a longer life. We become afraid of death. We would do anything just to stay alive. Even though we become miserable.
To a point where we actually forget to live. We simply just exist. We just survive without living. Without enjoying life.
Honestly, if we all took more risks in this life, you'd be seeing a lot more people appreciating, rather than complaining.

Vsauce, I recently had a huge debate amongs me and my freinds where we were talking about Statistics, and Avarages.
Where we split into two sides, Those who Think Statistic and Avarages are Correct.
And Those who think that Statistic and Avarages are not Correct.

The topic was mostly sentered around Video Games. Where we were discussin if you could Judge a player by Statistic in Random Matches against Random People through a completely unbiased Random Matchmaking system. You werent playing against people of certain skill level, but of all skill levels.
Would his statistic be valid to judge his skill? Or does actually player skill itself judged outside of Random matchmaking statistics?

In other words. One group was supporting the idea that if a player had 60% victory rate in random battles, he was a good player.
But the other group was against this, saying that only through non-randomized, organized battles like tournaments, would decide if the player is a good player or not.
As Random battles and matchmaking may or may not put Odds against you. You might be a good player, but have high number of people in your team who low skill. Thus stacking the odds of victory against you.
Or you might be a poor player, but your team consist of mostly good player with plenty of experience.
Makes me think about life again...

Michael, you and I need to hang out.

Survivalism is fundamentally ignoble - nonaryan, pre-neolitic. Survivalism at its core is a never ending mission, the mission is to stay alive.

Militarism is about staying alive insofar it serves the fulfillment of a grander idealistic mission (whatever that may be). Such a mindset can be read in civilizations in which a worthy life is paired with an equally worthy death (not by an equally worth longevity), societies purposefully self-aware of their own mortality struggle to achieve something greater that an individual's own limited existence, never regretting their own physical finiteness.

As opposed to a modern day Zurich in which a funeral carriage is not allowed to travel during the day.

Here's a question that I would like answered: What if we keep living longer?

Advances in Medical Science have the statistics that someone born today might live to be 125-150 years old in good health. So what if the Medical Science keeps advancing and we keep living longer and longer?
Now, not only to mention the drastic increase in population in the last 50 years alone, but the depletion of Earth's natural resources at an incredible rate, where would we be in the next 100-500 years?
I don't want to imagine some planet like Philip K. Dick's "Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep," where everything on Earth is filled with "clutter" (the trash and remnants of previous inhabitants who have moved to another inhabitable planet), the robotic animals because real animals are scarce, and the Earth is mostly filled with constant world-wide sand storms and technology has advanced so much that we've developed helper androids -- but is that really most likely going to be our future at the rate we're going?

Thanks Vsauce! I read about the story of the fighter planes in one of my statistics textbooks about "interpreting data." As an actuary (someone who analyzes risk) I can confirm everything that was said. Insurance companies, Obamacare, etc. put a lot of resources into retrieving data on mortality, loss, and general liability from risk. Insurance, healthcare, and the like are some of the most government regulated industries in the country; so regulated that companies struggle to even use general economic theories like supply and demand. Analyzing the unpredictable is a very tricky thing. Obamacare gave a lot of actuaries a job in trying to optimize its system.

Ah, risk. I've read a lot of Bruce Schneier's stuff, and he goes into tons of detail on this. I'd like to think it's allowed me to think a bit more rationally and be a bit less anxious over the years. For instance: 

"People exaggerate spectacular but rare risks and downplay common risks. They worry more about earthquakes than they do about slipping on the bathroom floor, even though the latter kills far more people than the former. Similarly, terrorism causes far more anxiety than common street crime, even though the latter claims many more lives. Many people believe that their children are at risk of being given poisoned candy by strangers at Halloween, even though there has been no documented case of this ever happening."

He covers similar ground to parts of this video in his essays "Perceived Risk vs. Actual Risk" and "Our Newfound Fear of Risk". It's great stuff.

2:45 Something is more likely to happen because it happened recently or there are more example of it happening available in our memories. In a sense this is true, but it only applies to individuals not everybody at once.
For example, if you race dirt bikes and you've crashed before and seen other people crash, you will have a higher probability of crashing again than people who don't race dirt bikes. Everybody has the potential to crash on a dirt bike, but your probability of crashing is higher because not everybody races dirt bikes.
So yes, an individual's life experiences and past choices do effect the probability of future events. However, an individual's experiences and choices don't have a significant impact on the probability of something bad happening to someone else.
